div.head: MS III Third Poetry Anthology
div.p: Ruskin compiled this anthology in MS III around 9 March 1829, apparently in response to his parentsʼ criticism that he tended to leave projects unfinished. The anthology occupies pages following “Harry and Lucy, Vol. 2,” and the MS III Second Poetry Anthology. For dating and discussion, see “Of rocks first and of caverns now I sing”: Date, and “Another” (“Far towards Chelsea”). The anthology contains the following poems, in order of their appearance:

list.item: “Of rocks first and of caverns now I sing”;
“The Adventures of an Ant: A Tale”;
“On the Appearance of a Sudden Cloud of Yellow Fog Covering Everything with Darkness”;
“A Fragment” (“The summit of skiddaw was gilt by the sun”);
“A Fragment” (“The world that in its orbit flies”);
“Another” (“On the noble Ben Lomond arose the bright sun”);
“Another” (“Thy winding rivers scotland and thy rocks”);
“A Psalm” (“I will extol thee O my Lord”).

div.p: The anthology wraps around two drawings, which probably predated the poems:

list.item: Drawing, MS III ???, untitled no. 2 (within “Of rocks first and of caverns now I sing”); and

Drawing, MS III ???, untitled no. 3 (following “The Adventures of an Ant: A Tale” and a page, blank except for the notation “chap 7,” and before “On the Appearance of a Sudden Cloud of Yellow Fog Covering Everything with Darkness”).
